The focus of MGMT104 is the economic and institutional constraints on organizations in the formulation and implementation of human resources management policies and strategies in the United States and, as appropriate, internationally. The specific constraints discussed are labor markets (external and internal), labor laws (governing employment policies and employee relations), and labor unions (and the threat thereof). Particular attention is paid to the relationship of these constraints to the competitiveness of American enterprise in the global economy. 

Feedback for this course was mixed. One student commented that the “material is extremely useful in understanding the different methods of employee motivation and compensation.” One student felt it was an “excellent course for any business student.” Others felt that the material was “boring” and “not useful.” 

Professor Barankay was overall well received by his students. Many students liked that he incorporated a “wide range of academic articles and experiments” but others complained that his teaching style was “very repetitive.”

Course requirements include class participation, an individual paper, a group paper, and two tests. Students agreed that there was “a lot of required reading.” Many students expressed that they would have appreciated “more detailed guidelines and rubrics.” Students also expressed frustration with the format of the second test, which “seemed to test how much could be written in a short period of time rather than knowledge course concepts.”
